lessons.title: Lesson 1: Early Internet Foundations (Before the Web)
lessons.content:
1960s – ARPANET:
The US Department of Defense started ARPANET, the first packet-switching network.
Allowed computers to communicate over long distances.
1970s – TCP/IP:
Protocols like TCP/IP were developed to standardize communication between computers.
This laid the foundation for the modern Internet.
1980s – Internet Growth:
Networks connected universities and research centers.
Email and file transfers became popular among scientists.
At this point, there was no web, just networks of computers sharing information.

lessons.title: Lesson 2: Birth of the World Wide Web (WWW)
lessons.content:
1989 – Tim Berners-Lee (a British scientist at CERN) proposed a system to share documents via the Internet.
1990 – First Web Implementation:
He created:
HTML (HyperText Markup Language) – to structure documents.
HTTP (HyperText Transfer Protocol) – to transfer pages over the Internet.
URL (Uniform Resource Locator) – to locate resources online.
The first web page was info.cern.ch, explaining the WWW project.
1991 – The Web Goes Public:
The WWW became available outside CERN.
Anyone could create web pages using HTML.
So, the Web ≠ Internet, but it runs on the Internet. The Web made the Internet user-friendly.

lessons.title: Lesson 3: Early Web Browsers
lessons.content:
1993 – Mosaic Browser:
First browser to display text and images together.
Made the Web accessible to ordinary users.
1994 – Netscape Navigator:
Popularized web browsing for the public.
Introduced innovations like cookies.

lessons.title: Lesson 4: Evolution of the Web
lessons.content:
Web 1.0 (1991–2004):
Static pages, read-only content.
Mostly informational websites.
Web 2.0 (2004–present):
Interactive and social websites.
Users can create content: Facebook, YouTube, Wikipedia.
Web 3.0 (emerging):
Semantic Web, decentralization, AI integration.
Users and machines interact more intelligently.

lessons.title: Lesson 5: Key Milestones
lessons.content:
1989
Tim Berners-Lee proposes WWW
1990
First website at CERN
1993
Mosaic browser released
1994
Netscape Navigator popularized web browsing
1995
JavaScript invented (dynamic web)
1998
Google founded (search revolution)
2004
Facebook launched (social web)
2007
Mobile web boom begins (smartphones)

⚡ Summary
The Internet is the global network of computers.
The World Wide Web (WWW) is a system of linked documents accessed via browsers.
HTML, HTTP, and URLs are the core building blocks of the Web.
Tim Berners-Lee is the father of the Web, making it easy to share and access information.
